Translation of 楚竹書・内豊(en) into English.

p.seg: As for the gentleman establishing filial virtue,
caring is what he employs,
ritual propriety what he holds dear.
Therefore as for acting as ruler of the people
to talk about the ruler of the people not being able to employ his ministers,
is not as good as talking about the minister of the people being unable to serve his lord.
Therefore as for acting as minister of the people,
to talk about the minister of the people being unable to serve his lord,
is not as good as talking about the ruler of the people not being able to serve his ministers.
Therefore as for acting as father of someone,
to talk about the father of someone not being able to rear his children,
is not as good as talking about someone’s son not being filial.
Therefore as for acting as someone’s son,
talking about someone’s son not being filial,
is not as good as talking about someone’s father not being able to rearing his children.
Therefore as for acting as someone’s brother,
talking about someone’s elder brother not being able of affection for his younger brother,
is not as good as talking about someone’s younger brother not being able to support his elder brother.
Therefore as for acting as someone’s younger brother,
talking about someone’s younger brother not being able to support his elder brother,
is not as good as talking about someone’s elder brother not being able of affection for his younger brother.
So he said,
when one talks with a lord,
one should talk about using ministers,
when one talks with a minister,
one should talk about serving the lord,
when one talks with a father,
one should talk about rearing children,
when one talks with a son,
one should talk about being filial towards one’s parents,
when one talk with an older brother,
one should talk about affection for younger brothers,
when one talks with a younger brother
one should talk about supporting elder brothers.
Going against this there will be chaos.
When a gentleman serves his parents,
there should be no private pleasure,
there should be no private pain.
What the parents like, one should like it,
what the parents find painful, one should find it painful.
If (what they like) is good,
then one should follow it,
if (what they like) is not good,
then one should stop it.
If one tries to stop it
and it is not permitted,
one should keep hidden
and bear what is not admissible.
Even until death,
obey them.
To be filial
and not to remonstrate,
is not being completely [filial.
To remonstrate
and not to obey them (even when they are wrong),
is also] not being completely filial.
A gentlemanly filial son does not defeat (his parents, by openly contradicting them),
he hides (his true opinion) in his most intimate (??)
and tries skillfully to transform (their opinion),
so that his parents feel at ease with it,
as if it has arisen from themselves.
The gentleman says:
"a filial son, if his parents are sick,
wears the cap without coiling up (his hairs),
walks without ritual demeanor,
does not stand in groups,
does not talk much.
At dawn he performs the gong and ying ritual,
he performs prayers for the five sacrifices,
will there not be necessarily an improvement (in their health),
so that the gentleman will thereby perfect his filial piety?
This is what one calls a gentleman."
The gentleman said:
if a filial son serves his parents by feeding them,
how is this to be reputed beautiful?
I repute it (merely to be) the lowest level (of filial piety)
The gentleman said:
"brotherly love is the norm of the people.
One should not fight for small things,
one should not make disorder for great things.
Therefore the young should necessarily follow the orders of the elder,
the lowly should necessarily follow the order of the noble.
If one follows the exhortation (of one’s superiors),
then one escapes from grief.
